summary: On July 24, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine entered summary judgment against a Maine-based grocery store and its owner in a civil action brought by a Somali immigrant community.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in Portland, Maine, alleges that Mahdi Irobe and Suuqa Bakaro Grocery, LLC, a Lewiston, Maine grocery store, violated the antifraud provisions of Section 2023 of the federal securities laws.  According to the complaint, Irobe allegedly engaged in a pattern of transactions that, in its view, evinced trafficking and permanently disqualified the store from participating in the federal program.  In addition, the complaint alleges that the Store engaged in 205 high-dollar transactions, that is, transactions ranging from $174 to $1,050, during the four-month period from July through October 2015.  As alleged, the Store's receipt of these transactions was inconsistent with the normal shopping behavior of SNAP-qualified households, and in the bargain, incentivizes shopkeepers to conduct legitimate business side-by-side with unlawful trafficking.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, the store consented to the entry of a final judgment that imposes a lifetime program-participation ban on all but one of its vendors, permanently enjoining it from violating the federal registration provisions of Sections 206(1) and 206(2) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 206(4)-8 thereunder, and ordering the Store to pay a civil penalty of $250,000, which is equal to the amount of disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties that will be imposed by the court upon the affected retailer.    In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against Irobe. Â The SEC's Office of Inspector General has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool onÂ Securities.gov.  Investors can also use theÂ SEC'sÂ Adviser.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.Â In a related matter, the Department of Health and Human Services today announced that it has obtained a court order requiring it to order a temporary restraining order against certain of Irobe's alleged violations of the anti-trafficking provisions of the Federal Trade Commission's (FTC) Rules of Practice, including Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5(a) thereunder.
